texts.value: Proton-dependent transporter of monocarboxylates such as L-lactate and pyruvate (PubMed:11101640, PubMed:23935841, PubMed:31719150). Plays a predominant role in L-lactate efflux from highly glycolytic cells (By similarity)
Interacts with BSG; interaction mediates SLC16A3 targeting to the plasma membrane

Plasma membrane localization is dependent upon the BSG/MCT4 interaction (PubMed:10921872). Basolateral sorting signals (BLSS) in C-terminal cytoplasmic tail ensure its basolateral expression in polarised epithelial cells (PubMed:21199217)
Up-regulated by hypoxia through a HIF1A-mediated mechanism
Two basolateral sorting signals (BSS) in its C-terminal cytoplasmic tail are required to direct SLC16A3 to the basolateral membrane
Belongs to the major facilitator superfamily. Monocarboxylate porter (TC 2.A.1.13) family

Was initially thought to be considered to be a low affinity lactate transporter with negligible affinity for pyruvate (PubMed:11101640). However, it was later shown that SLC16A3 is a high affinity lactate transporter with physiologically relevant affinity for pyruvate (PubMed:31719150)
Was initially assigned as monocarboxylate transporter 3 (MCT3) (PubMed:9425115). However, it was later shown that it corresponds to monocarboxylate transporter 4 (MCT4)

comments.resourceName: Atlas of Genetics and Cytogenetics in Oncology and Haematology

features.description: Does not affect lactate transmembrane transporter activity.
Abolishes lactate transmembrane transporter activity. Does not affect cell membrane localization.
Affects subcellular localization leading to apical localization. Affects subcellular localization leading to apical localization; when associated with A-426 and A-427.
Leads to a nonpolar expression pattern. Affects subcellular localization leading to apical localization; when associated with A-425 and A-427.
Affects subcellular localization leading to apical localization. Affects subcellular localization leading to apical localization; when associated with A-425 and A-426.
Does not affect basolateral plasma membrane localization. Intracellular accumulation. Affects subcellular localization leading to apical localization; when associated with A-433.
Does not affect basolateral plasma membrane localization. Intracellular accumulation. Affects subcellular localization leading to apical localization; when associated with A-432.

citation.title: Cloning and sequencing of four new mammalian monocarboxylate transporter (MCT) homologues confirms the existence of a transporter family with an ancient past.

Characterisation of human monocarboxylate transporter 4 substantiates its role in lactic acid efflux from skeletal muscle.
Presence and localization of three lactic acid transporters (MCT1, -2, and -4) in separated human granulocytes, lymphocytes, and monocytes.
Global, in vivo, and site-specific phosphorylation dynamics in signaling networks.
